It's a broadcast ratings milestone that prior to now had not been reached. Therefore it is relevant to the state of broadcast ratings. Was it unexpected that this milestone would be reached? No. But that is not a requirement for relevance. *Titanic* becoming the first movie to gross over $1 billion was relevant to the movie industry, Roger Bannister being the first man to break the four minute mile was relevant to athletics, in spite of both events being expected based on previous trends.

'Pattern Day Trading' specifically only applies to margin accounts. Day trading is not specifically forbidden in cash accounts, you just have to do it without incurring Reg T violations.

"What people signed up for" was inherently unsustainable. Netflix benefited greatly from being among the first to realize the value of streaming, but the companies that owned the content were inevitably going to catch on and have, leading to vastly increased costs for Netflix to continue licensing their content. So Netflix's options are massive price increases or a shift towards less licensed content and more original content, and they chose the latter.
That rule is just for margin accounts. But T+3 settlement will make doing much day trading in a small cash account difficult.

It amounts to the pretty much the same thing. ESPN may be listed as ~$7 a month, but it's only that low because its price is effectively subsidized by the prices of the "filler" channels. You'd never get stand-alone ESPN for that little. And again, what you consider "filler" will not be the opinion held by everyone. There will inevitably be some people who watch the "Indoor Flyfishing Channel" and not ESPN but pay for both; they're subsidizing the cost of ESPN for everyone else.
The bottom line is that for people who consume lots of content, a la carte will inevitably be more expensive than bundling (which is entirely consistent with a la carte menus in other situations). But again, a la carte itself isn't what a lot people really wanted; mostly they just wanted to pay far less for what they currently watch, and thought a la carte would guarantee that because they didn't actually think things through. Now that we're actually getting closer to a la carte with streaming services, they'll have to face the reality of the situation.

it's a cooler nickname than Reverse-Flash
Disagree.

it's that the channels which are desirable are being used to subsidize all the ones that aren't
But which channels are "desirable" varies by viewer and that goes both ways: I'm paying for channels I don't watch, but the channels I watch are subsidized by people who who pay for them but don't watch them. Switch everything to a la carte and you'd get to drop the channels you don't want, but you'd have to pay more for the channels you do want because they'd no longer be subsidized by others.
If you only want a few channels (with streaming services effective being a 'channel' for comparison) then a la carte makes good sense and would save you money. But if you want large amounts of content then a la carte was always going to be more expensive than bundling. Which people are now seeing (though it should have been obvious).
Hence why I never watch this show sober.

It's because what people WANTED was the option to pick and choose channels for a dollar or two a month
What people really wanted was the same content they were already getting but for a fraction of the price. Which was obviously never going to be viable.

Yeah, seriously. It doesn't take into account the multitude of ways that a show can be viewed at all, it only counts when people watch it on tv when it aired.
Well its main purpose is to measure how many people watched the commercials, and most of the other ways people would watch a show have either no commercials or different ones from the original broadcast.

Nielsen's main purpose is to measure how many people watch the commercials in a show and serve as a metric for pricing the sale of said commercials. That it marginalizes DVR viewers and ignores stuff like Netflix is a feature, not a flaw, since advertisers aren't going to pay for viewers that skipped the commercials on DVR or watched without commercials on Netflix. As for Hulu and Netflix, what matters to network/studio isn't necessarily the number of people watching a show on Netflix/Hulu but the amount of $$ that Netflix/Hulu are paying for the show, neither of which are typically disclosed to the public.

Reddit seems to love think that TV execs (aside from the CW) are ignorant dinosaurs with no concept of things like streaming. Nevermind that every major broadcast network has and advertises its own streaming site/app, SVOD is a major part of current syndication deals, stacking rights are a big part of the negotiations for picking up new shows, etc. The big networks/studios may have undervalued the importance of streaming when it first hit the scene, but they've long since caught on.
Now I would believe that the CW puts more weight on streaming than the Big 4 when it comes to renewal decisions, not because the CW knows anything the others don't but because the CW's revenue from its linear channel is much lower than for the Big 4 and the difference may not be as great for other revenue sources.

If you go look at the airdates for long running shows there are really only breaks for holidays and sports or political special presentations.
I've actually gone back and looked at airdates for shows from back in the day to investigate this very question, and they typically had lots of breaks that weren't for holidays or special events (which fits with what you expect from stretching 22-25 episodes over the course of the entire TV season). I think people just don't remember that because in-season reruns used to be a lot more common and people weren't bothered by the breaks like they are now.
IIRC the reason recent live-action versions don't put the symbol on the back of the cape is that it makes the CGI easier, so I wouldn't expect that to change.

I remember it used to be fairly clear cut...TV seasons would start in September or October, run until mid-December and go on hiatus for a winter break...then come back around the end of January just in time for February sweeps and run until early/mid-May when the season finales would air.
You're leaving out the numerous weeks of reruns that would be sprinkled in there.

Neflix having its own deal with the WGA means that shows produced by Netflix won't be affected by this.
But Netflix itself doesn't produce very much content. Most Netflix Originals are produced by other studios and sold to Netflix, so if those studios are affected by the strike that will delay those shows and thus affect Netflix.

Live views are the most significant part for season renewals.
C3 and C7 views are what matter for renewals, because those are what advertisers are paying for. Live ratings have not been the main currency used in selling TV commercials for years now.
So yes, if you watch it on DVR it's true that that won't count towards Live ratings, but that's not important. If you watch on DVR within three days and don't skip the commercials that will count towards C3 ratings (likewise for C7 ratings), which are what actually matter when it comes to renewal because those are what the network's customers are paying for.

the shit network where successful shows come to die
If a broadcast show is getting shit ratings then it isn't successful.
Now in some occasions it can make sense to blame the network for a show's lack of success (such as airing episodes of a serialized show out of order), but usually the show just isn't effective enough at attracting viewers.
